title: Where Story Happens.
body:
Hey everyone,

Welcome to the Story and Art board! 

If you’re an old soul from the previous boards, you may have noticed these aren't the forums you're used to, and maybe that change is a little intimidating. But we don't want your interactions with other players to be any different than they were on our forums.

If you’re new here, you may be wondering: what IS this place, and what is it for? 

Let’s run it down with some guidelines:

* This is a place to talk about or speculate on existing stories and champions. Digging Xerath’s betrayal of Azir? The rivalry between Garen and Darius? Graves and Twisted Fate’s ongoing tension? Talk about it here! 

* Fanfiction, fanart, champion concepts, and other lovely things like that should NOT be posted here. This board is for discussion on League of Legends’ canon story.

* Upvote/downvote on content! Votes are your friends! Downvotes should be used for comments and discussions that aren't relevant or don’t add to the discussion - they shouldn't be used to express disagreement with another player.

* Use those filters! There are filters on each Board that let you sort by Recent, Hot, or Best. We've also implemented a much better search function on Boards. Seriously, it's much more effective than the old forums.

Also, we’ve recently done a lot of story things you may have missed – here are a few links to get the discussion going! CHECK 'EM:

[Dev Blog: Exploring Runeterra ](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/creative-spotlight/dev-blog-
exploring-runeterra)

[Shurima Event Main Page](http://promo.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/shurima/index.html)

[Descent into the Tomb](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JKnM6Hh5gOg)

(Shurima Part 1)

[Rise of the Ascended](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CYyuH1Bp2ZI)

(Shurima Part 2)

Hope everyone enjoys the discussion here! 

Thanks,
The Riot Narrative Team

""Does this mean older story efforts like the Journal of Justice and League Judgments are meaningless? Of course not. In the same way that we can go back and enjoy old books, shows, films, art, and comics that have been superseded by more recent interpretations of the same material, League’s original lore remains a cherished part of its history. From comic books to classic literature, exploration of the same creative space in vastly different ways is a natural part of storytelling.""

I am still confused on what is canon and what no longer is canon in terms of lore. It's hard to discuss anything because everything seems to be uncertain at this moment, besides everything pertaining to the Shurima event. What I have taken from the quote from the dev blog. Everything post-Shurima event will now be canon, and everything pre-Shurima event should be treated as a different universe or a different telling of possible future events? (similar to comic books I guess?)

I suppose I would like a more concise or better clarification on what aspects of "old" lore is being kept and if we should just remember the "old" lore in fondness, or if we should still draw from it for discussions on the current lore.

> What I have taken from the quote from the dev blog. Everything post-Shurima event will now be canon, and everything pre-Shurima event should be treated as a different universe or a different telling of possible future events? (similar to comic books I guess?)

That's pretty close - what hasn't changed is any of the champions' personalities and the majority of what you know about them, to be honest. If you go through bios that mention the IoW, all you have to do is omit the League part in your brain. They're different canons, and we won't be expanding on the old one.

We normally alter a champion's story during an event or champ rework, so that they feel more cohesive with the new canon. You guys have seen this happen for the past two years or so.

For example, Cass is still from Noxus and Kat's sister, even though we've embedded her into the new Shurima story. She's still a seductress and a little less liked than Kat. But instead of having her cursed from Joe Schmoe from Freljord, we wanted her entwined (HEH) with a bigger storyline and other champions.

The core things you know about champions remain the same... For example, Nasus used to be a space librarian. Now he's not from space; his previous lore revolved around "How do we get him to Runeterra and care about it?!" and it *had him summoned to Runeterra against his will* - we don't want that constraint, and frankly, that plot point makes me super sad as a writer. But he still retains his personality and his relationship with his brother, since those are the things that are key to Nasus, not the fact that Summoners channeled him to fight for them for reasons.

Well I took away the league part of jax's lore and was left with a random hermit. What do?
What I took away from Lee's lore was that he light himself on fire to protest a war that never happened. And that he used to be a summoner that no longer exists.
I laughed really hard.

More seriously: I think Nasus being from Shurima is how it always should have been, sort of like Olaf with the Freljord. And I definitely don't hold the old lore sacred. A lot of it is, honestly, pretty goofy. Some gems were stumbled upon amid all that wackiness, but there was also a lot of painfully stupid material. I'm glad to see lore getting polished up. (I do get a little concerned when I see some of those gems being ground up with all the junk. If you ever make Veigar not a cuddly yordle who went crazy from lack of snuggles, or make Teemo not a sociopathic killer, or make Dr. Mundo a played-straight growly scary bruiser with a voice filter, I'll cry for days. Please keep a little silliness in LoL's lore.) All in all, good stuff.

For example: I think the new Sion lore is already a drastic improvement.

I mean, I'll probably still be mumbling about the Summoners retcon when they put me into a nursing home, but other than that, I do like what you're doing, Summoner Opeli.
I'm there with you. I think the old lore is pretty damn charming. There's something so... familiar and cozy about it.
The idea of having a league of legends and an institute of war has been pretty damn charming for you? apparently not charming enough. actions still speak louder than words.

> I'm there with you. I think the old lore is pretty damn charming. There's something so... familiar and cozy about it.

This comment made me so happy. Like I said, a lot of clean-up needs to be done, but I think LoL works in part because it's a little cartoony, a little insane, a little strange, a little fourth-wall-breaky. (To be honest, this is part of why I like the Summoners concept: I enjoy the self-acknowledged silliness of, e.g., translating connection problems into "chrono-distortion on the Fields of Justice".) It would make me sad to see Riot steamroll its distinctive, quirky, "garage startup" lore entirely into glossy cardboard. There are *so many* dark-and-gritty serious-business fantasy settings out there, and I think LoL stands out in part due to the splash of satire. It's almost like it's The Ultimate Showdown of Ultimate Destiny in video game form, a sort of "Mega Man versus Legolas" daydream brought to life. You could say it's a post-modern reflection upon fantasy as a whole.

There's some profundity in there, too. Although the proportions are markedly different, I'm somehow reminded of Terry Pratchett's Discworld, where some pretty heavy meaning and character depth sometimes bursts out of a very silly context to sock you a dose of unexpected enlightenment.

If I were to abstractly describe the sort of lore team I want to see working on this, it would go something like this: "Serious enough to feel compelled to replace weak stories with strong stories, but playful enough to appreciate LoL's charm and not make it just another fantasy setting."

What is driving ppl mad is that the "new lore" has been presented as a flat and shallow preview of the champions and their backgrounds. The Sion story is actually really charming, involving, well written and well presented, this is making me even more mad at the Shurima event (Xerath main here and I'm playing lot of Azir even with bugs). As you are doing with the balance changes (small steps towards the full rebalance with fast patches) same should be done with the Lore: Small sneaks, improvements to the bios of the champions creating suspance about what we could we get to know more and in a short time.

> As you are doing with the balance changes (small steps towards the full rebalance with fast patches) same should be done with the Lore: Small sneaks, improvements to the bios of the champions creating suspance about what we could we get to know more and in a short time.

Some real discussion that influences development wouldn't hurt, either. Like, say, some discussion before erasing the League of Legends from League of Legends, talking about alternatives and whether it's a good idea in the first place.

> The core things you know about champions remain the same... For example, Nasus used to be a space librarian. Now he's not from space; his previous lore revolved around "How do we get him to Runeterra and care about it?!" and it *had him summoned to Runeterra against his will* - we don't want that constraint, and frankly, that plot point makes me super sad as a writer. But he still retains his personality and his relationship with his brother, since those are the things that are key to Nasus, not the fact that Summoners channeled him to fight for them for reasons.

Sorry if I'm being thick, but how is being summoned from another world a constraint? If anything, it gives Nasus additional depth and complexity as a character. He's not just some dude from Shurima, he's got a whole 'nother culture and way of life that would be absolutely fascinating to explore. Just because something makes you "super sad as a writer" doesn't mean it's a bad idea - in fact, if you think it's sad, it's likely that the rest of us will too. This adds additional depth to Nasus's story and to his character. Is he upset at being on Runeterra? Ambivalent? Does he want to return to his home? It honestly gives you more room to develop him.

It would also honestly be easy to keep Nasus's otherwordly origins, but we can discuss that later :P

100% agree. I would love it if Nasus would say things like, 
"I'm only here to stop Renekton, Summoner. I won't be staying." 
or "It is very cute that you think you are holding me here."
or "This battle will end with time. I don't mind seeing it through." 
or "I suppose I can leave my research for a while to see your little conflict."

I see absolutely NO constraint in storytelling here. I hate that the previous lore is being abandoned. In fact, you could have an event where Nasus decides to leave, and summoners have to work hard to get him back/stop him. This could precede a new skin, where Nasus is furious at being controlled, perhaps wearing magical shackles. These are just off the top of my head here, I can come up with lots more, and I'm not being paid to do it like Riot is.

Okay, so the characters are still mostly the same. The primary questions I have, then, are twofold. What about, say, Fiddle and Nocturne, and those ilk? Are they just 'random evil monsters doing evil monster things?' everywhere?

But the big question is, what about Runeterra itself? Without the institute, there's no reason for Demacia and Noxus to not be fighting each other, for Zaun to not spew poisonous gas everywhere, etc. Are we supposed to assume that everything played out exactly the same, just with actual armies instead of summoners and champions?

Fiddlesticks, if nothing else is done, can simply have the league removed and he stays the same. He tried to aid the army of his people, magic ran amok, etc. As for Noc, was he ever *not* a random evil monster?

As for Runeterra, I can't speak for the lore team, but I'm sure (and I hope) we'll get that resolved sometime. I'm OK with the new changes, but this one is my biggest burning question.

Here's the thing

The Institute of War gave us a reason why random evil monsters like Nocturne would interact with other champions without mindlessly trying to kill them.

Instead of ADDING a paragraph to lore you DELETE what you have and replace it with far less.

Right now, there's two different Trundles (read the old lore+judgement and compare it with the new in-game presentation, especially voice-overs if you doubt this), are you just going to discard one or the other? I'd probably just try to quit League lore if you guys would just discard old Trundle like that, especially after this emphasis on keeping the core the same. I already withhold myself from fully investing into the new lore ever since his Freljord retconning (I don't care he's an ice troll, I care he's not Trundle), because if it is done to one character, it could happen to any character and the dev blog did imply the Freljord was part of the new lore.

My issue is that redoing his voice-overs takes quite some effort and reasonably, even if you wanted to address him, it'd take a lot of time and you wouldn't want to spoil it, but as long as it isn't done I can't enjoy the lore like I should. (His background is quite close to being old Trundle, surprisingly really if you consider his lines in-game.)

They were glorified spectators, making things up for themselves to fuel their own egos and delusions. Perhaps some strange magical artifact they brought in made them insane over time, planting the falsehood of their powers in their heads? And, renaming themselves after the riot that initially broke out when they all realized they were deceived by that strange artifact, they rename themselves Riot Games.
